Text: I focused on occupying the majority of the yellow continent with troops in yellow A, Yellow B, Yellow C, and Yellow D since this gave me a continent bonus and lots of territories close together. I put enough troops in countries that could be attacked so that I outnumbered the attacker, such as 2 troops in Yellow B since 1 grey troop in Red C could attack it. This also occurred at yellow C, if attacked by 3 troops from Blue A, so I put 4 troops there. I also kept all my troops close together to help me repel attacks. I sought to move in to continent blue and eventually continent green, which Is why I placed troops at the access points.

For me I saw that there were good opportunities for me to put troops on both Red and Blue, so I put 9 troops on Red and 5 on Blue This gives me great opportunities to win some battles and launch strategic attacks from Red, while still protecting both continents. Putting troops on Blue gives me access to yellow and the ability to fight the troops there. Controlling Red gives me access to purple, blue and yellow. I also need to only win one battle on both Red and Blue to control them which will give me troops and land to be able to win the game.

For me I decided to look at two continents which I was going to occupy. Those two continents happen to be red and purple. Continent red gave me the opportunity to put troops on two countries. So I decided to divide up nine troops which gives me the ability to fight the one country that has troops on there as well as protect red and attack blue on which only one country is controlled. Continent purple only has two troops on there so I decided to put five of my own to battle those two other as well as have the ability to cross over into green and fight the troops that are on that continent. So right now I have access to all the continents with my positioning of the troops that I have. Giving me a great chance to fight a lot, which is one of my goals.

My goal here is to take over Blue as soon as possible. It should be easy to defeat the 2 troops there - I can then move on to the real battle on Yellow. I have 5 troops there but since I have a continent now, I can add more troops to Yellow and take it over. With Yellow and Blue totally under my control, I have access paths to Green and Purple. I will move from Yellow to Green and attempt a defeat of the 4 troops there and take it over as well. Red and Purple will be the battlegrounds for sure as they are heavily fortified. Red will have to be first to get attacked then Purple.

Purple, Red, and Yellow are all tightly occupied, so I can only afford to place troops on one of those three. I decided to go for Yellow, as I have enough troops to overpower them (hopefully). I'd like to conquer Yellow and make it my base. Meanwhile, I stationed troops in Green B to flank the opponent's troops in Green A. Between my Yellow and Green troops, there is nowhere for the opponent to run to.

My strategy this time is to overwhelm smaller territories with smaller troops. I've placed 14 troops all in one red territory that has access to blue B and yellow B. I plan on defending red and conquering yellow and blue.

I wanted to attempt to quickly take over a territory so I could have a better chance at expanding my troops with bonus from occupying said territory. I chose Green because most of the countries in it were unoccupied and the ones that were occupied had a low amount of troops. Next, I wanted the border countries of my territory to have extra troops in case someone tried to attack and steal one of the outside countries. I also put most troops near the enemy country in my continent as I plan on attacking it early.

Red is a desirable continent because it only has one incoming path, which makes it highly defensible. Additionally, since there were no enemy troops in any Red country I could easily seize Red during the troop deployment phase. The Red continent also possesses one of two paths into the Purple continent. By placing my remaining troops into Purple_A, I was able to posses the only other country in Purple with incoming paths. Although the black player does have 5 troops in Purple, I am confident that the numerical advantage I will gain by holding all of the Red continent will allow me to eliminate the black forces in the Purple continent early in the game. This will allow me to control two entire continents by only defending two territories, and over time controlling these two continents will give me a huge advantage in troop numbers compared to the two other players. Since Red also has an outgoing path to every other continent, I will be able to easily use my troop advantage to prevent the other players from controlling other continents.

I wanted to place troops on purple since there were no other troops there and because it would let me attack the Green continent. I decided to place troops on yellow since there were not too many enemy troops on that continent. I think it will be easy to play a defensive strategy on yellow by having five of my troops on each country and ten troops total on the continent.

I wanted to control the continent of green to give me that advantage so I used troops in most territories there. I choose to go into Blue to get assess to purple and I also choose to go into yellow to get as much spread across all boards as possible. I could not get into red until I beat this opponent. I feel it is important to be spread out in early game to be able to make strategic attacks and gain as much territory as possible as soon as possible. This will not only intimidate opponents. I want to move on others troops fast and hard and get it over quickly before they can have time to think about what just happened. I feel my aggressive nature will help me prevail and win the game quickly. I also like to control the borders when possible just seems safer option to me. I think I can quickly take over yellow and blue and then move on purple and finally red as they are more consitranted best to leave them for last. They will be more stuck on one side of the board to I will be able to rain down on them

The map is fragmented this round so I wanted to take countries that could battle for other territories. Purple_A could attack and take Green_E, Green_D could attack and take Red_A, and Green_A could easily defend itself from Yellow_D. I took Green_B for the sake of having more countries under my control. I avoided placing troops on Yellow and Blue because it looks like the other two players are about to clash on those continents and I don't want to be crushed between them.

I want to make Red my stronghold. If I control Red, I can send attack Purple and move to Blue easily. I placed troops on Blue B, so that I could move troops from Red to Blue easily to fortify that country. I placed troops on Green E and Purple A, so that I could control that entrance to both continents.

I wanted to move most of the troops to one territory and attack one opponent at a time. I wanted to make sure that I would have enough troops to have a good chance at a successful attack. I chose to only go after one opponent at a time to maximize the number of troops on one territory. Green will be my base but I want troops on a second continent as a backup.

I have to move more troops to defend any attacks, then after i will move them to the surrounding boarders.  I want to maximize my attacks and then move troops to concord the continents.  I want to start moving my troops to start dominating the board and win the game. I am moving more troops to different borders to dominate the board.  Trying to gain access to more continents.

I need to be able to attack Purple because they got a good amount of troops in Purple_A. I need to be able to have access to them and that is why I decided to put some of my troops on Red, Green, and Blue. I take risk for having some of my troops on red just to gain access purple, because Green also has a good amount of troops and they have access to Red as well. I again like that Red has access to all 4 of the continents. Even if they don't have the biggest territory, I believe with the right amount of troops and tactics it would be very possible to beat other continents. Blue also has access to Purple and that way they can work together to take a big competitor out of the way. Blue isn't very strong, but I believe it could gain with the turns in the game. I feel like it is important to also put some of your troops in the places most people don't think about putting them cause that way they can have the surprise of the underdog. Having access is very important, just as having a good amount of troops in each territory to begin the game. Attacking the biggest continent with the most troops should be a priority and expanding your troops to surrounding them is a good way of doing so.

My strategy is to control Yellow and Blue if possible. The same player control two yellow countries and one blue country, and will have to get through the player on purple in order to move anywhere on that continent. So I think that I can quickly take out the one troop on Blue C by placing troops on blue B, and also defend against an attack from red. I felt I needed most troops (8) on Blue B in order to do this. I plan to only attack yellow, because I think that the black player will likely take care of the grey player for me on that continent, since they have the most access to them on purple.

Red I feel is the central part of the map. I almost even believe that is why the map shows it so far out to trick you to think it isn't. I think Red would be the place to go, to make sure you can get to everyone quickly and start to take over each continent one at a time.

Yellow is an easy continent to occupy as there is only 1 country with 1 troop to worry about.  I can defend Yellow from Blue by having 6 troops defending the border.  Blue is the only country Yellow needs to worry about.  With 2 troops in Yellow D, I can think about attacking Green.  Red is in prime position to attack both Purple and Green.  With no one attacking from Green yet, and only 4 troops on the continent, my remaining troops can occupy the other two countries, attack and occupy Red C, and then plan my Purple invasion.

I want to take control of Green and Red as they are least populated and thus easiest to start a base from. My attack strategy is three-pronged. First I will attack the grey player in Green C to start seizing control of Green. Next I will attack the black player in Red C to seize control of Red. Finally, I will use Red B to start invading Purple and fight the black player there. I will leave 2 troops on Green A to defend against possible incursion from Yellow. I do not want to have any troops on Yellow or Blue, as I believe that the grey and black players will be fighting there and I want to avoid too much unnecessary conflict.

I focused on having troops stationed in the purple continent where I put troops at Purple A, Purple B, and Purple E. I made sure to put enough troops at Purple A and Purple E, 3 and 5 respectively, to protect against attacks from other continents, with some extra troops in Purple B as backup. This gave me 10 total troops to protect purple with. In this way I protected the borders of continent purple. I also stationed troops at Green E, with enough troops to counter an attack from the neighboring green countries that grey controls. I also had access to Green E from the purple continent where most of my troops were.

The ability to be able to attack at any moment off of Red is ideal to me. I try to just continue to stay on top of all of it. I wanted to make sure I was able to attack any enemy on any continent at a moments notice. It would be the most beneficial to me. I need to maintain 4 troops on the countries I want to defend. There's no point going to purple until I control red.

I wanted to occupy all the available sections left on the green and purple countries. I also wanted to protect their borders by places more troops in areas where other troops could challenge us to a battle. I did avoid as many battles as I could to try to keep the sections that I occupy. Although red was completely available, I did not place any troops there because their battles would lead to too many different sections in other countries.

In this game my goal is to try to take control of purple as soon as possible so that I can use that in an attempt to help take over green to get to red where I will have a strategic advantage to get to the rest of the continents. Yellow is too heavily occupied in this one for it to be practical for me to try to attack from the beginning so I will need to plan out and fortify the rest of the continents first. My strategy requires troops to be spread out.

Given that there were no enemies at all in red continent, my main goal here was to completely occupy it from the start as none of my opponents were able to do the same. In placing troops in Red_A, Red_B and Red_C I would accomplish that before the game even started. Additionally, having six troops at Red_A would allow me to have access to the green continent early on in the game while protecting Red from attacks. Further, having troops at Red_B would allow me to have access to purple continent early on. Additionally, troops in Red_C would give me direct access to both the yellow and blue continents throughout the game. I could accomplish all of these things in one move because of my positioning. Furthermore, because I owned one continent early on, I would have access to more troops per turn then my opponents, giving me the ability to conquer blue continent and yellow continent quicker than my enemies could. I needed at least three countries in order to own all of red continent and in having troops in all countries there I can actively reinforce and prevent direct attacks until I have enough troops in each to actively attack other countries later on.

I have decided to dominate the red Continent as it has the capability to attack but not get attacked by an external continent. I will defend Red with all might. I have also scattered out some soldiers out to green and yellow in order to implement a divide and conquer strategy. My ultimate goal is to occupy as many continents as I can by attacking in all directions and eventually purple.

So this is again the strategy of taking color and holding it while growing beyond our lines. Very much a Roman empire style. I Plan to march My Blue D troops south to take out the enemy in Blue C. This allows me to control the area for extra troops on my next round. I then plan to march north with the soldiers from My Blue A  squad and start securing the yellow continent for myself. I will, however, leave a larger mass of troops in the Blue B as I gain troop to protect against  the red Invasion

On this map I decided to go after continent purple. I saw that the continent was empty and so I decided to put all 14 of my troops within two of the countries on the continent. These two countries give me the opportunity to fend off attacks from continent blue, green as well as red. I decided to go with this strategy because I believe that I could fend off the attacks from all those continents and win those battles. Right now I only have the ability to launch an attack against green. But I believe that I can overtake them and then start to move across the continent giving me the opportunity to move into yellow as well as red later in the game. That is the best way for me to not only protect the border of the continent I'm on but slowly start to creep into other areas of the map and gain as much control as I can to win the game.

Because Green_E is already in my hands, and close to the edge, I can attack Purple_A very well. Yellow_B is easy to be attacked by red, so be defensive. The same applies to blue_B, purple_B and purple_E. In short, those who are likely to be attacked must do a good job of protection, and those who have the opportunity to attack other places must prepare sufficient troops.

The yellow continent is ripe for taking since all four of its countries are available. I will use all of my troops to control yellow. I will fortify yellow b and c with four troops each in order to defend them from the grey player. I will also hold a strong position in yellow d in order for a future attack on green a, which black currently controls. Yellow a will be the reserves. I will avoid putting troops on all the other continents, since it looks like black and grey will be fighting over them.

I placed my troops on Blue and Purple so that my troops would outnumber the other players troops. I wanted my troops to be able to dominate my continents, so I made sure to have at least 6 troops on each continent. Placing two troops in each country also gave me a better chance to defend my countries from invasions.

My strategy for this game is to begin the game occupying all of the yellow territory so I have that extra troop bonus from the complete occupation. I kept 4 soldiers on yellow C and on yellow D to be able to attack and defend from the blue territory and from the green territory. I also placed troops on green B to be able to attack either green A or green D depending on the needs for the rest of the game.

Red is open with no enemies which allows me to get the continent bonus along with country bonuses for three countries. The only way to get to red is going through a country in green continent, so as long as I am properly defended from the one entry point with 4 troops, I can attack all other countries without them attacking back. I can also move troops to all other continents as needed which will allow me to attack each continent and all the other players while keeping other from getting the continent bonuses.

My strategy is to put a majority of my troops in the red continent to conquer it early.  A minimum detachment of 2 troops will be put to defend purple A from an early invasion from the blue continent.  I aim to control the purple continent next, then push into green E while reinforcing purple A.

I think overall it would be great to gain the most amount of troops added. I would gain the additional troops for having a troop on at least one of every continent and then more based on the total continent of red. I think this would maximize the amount of troops I could get and land me in a good place for winning.

For me there was only one continent that I wanted to put troops on. Pulling troops on continent red was going to give me the ability to have access to continents green and purple in one move. I also have the ability to battle the one country that's occupied on continent red to try and gain control of the entire continent. That is why I put all 14 of my troops on continent red, surrounding the other player's country. If I win the battle on red I will be able to fortify and protect the continent as well as be able to launch attacks on both yellow and blue from there, so it won't matter that I only control two countries at the start of the game.

I want to surround green c and take the continent over, so I spread my troops over the 4 surrounding green territories. I will my troops to take green c from the grey player, who only has 3 troops there. There is no present threat right now from red a or purple a, so I didn't put many troops on those borders. I want to stand strong in green a in case grey decides to attack from yellow d. I put 4 troops there in case this happens. I would look to attack either red or purple after I controlled the entirety of green.

This map is one that I thought was going to give me the opportunity to be able to control a continent since blue is empty. Seeing blue empty made me immediately turn my attention to it. I decided to fortify it by putting 10 troops five in one country and five in another. From there I was going to be able to attack two continents as well as defend blue as best I could. I also decided to put troops in yellow. Putting them in yellow gives me the opportunity to battle on yellow do you control of some troops there as well as help fortify the continent if I can win some battles by having blue troops advance over there as well. So my focus was blue with the opportunity to go after yellow and from yellow go to green and gain damage there.

My idea was to, as quickly as possible, take an entire continent and secure it's borders while also giving myself a way off the continent to attack other players. Green was the least occupied continent on the board with only two units in one territory. By placing an overwhelming force, I could quickly eliminate those two units, take over the continent and have an overwhelming force to protect my threatened boarders. I also placed a lot of units in Green D because, not only could I attack Green E and eliminate the two units there, but I could also attack Red A and eliminate the one unit there, expanding off of Green. The units on Yellow are placed away from my borders, so I placed only a few units there to protect my border without necessarily threatening theirs hoping they will leave me alone while I take over the Red continent.

I decided to stay put everything on blue again on this map.  I think I need to make sure that I defend the continent and not let any other players get it.  Purple seems to be pretty strong right now so it's not the right time.

I think I can take control of the green continent here. It's quite exposed and it looks to me like the armies on purple a and purple e will be going at it. Red b will also most likely get involved with that. I can probably take green a and have control over the entire Green continent. I'll probably be in a bad condition if I don't occupy at least 4 countries at all times.

As I looked at the board I wanted to spread my troops to three continents. On those continents I was just going to occupy one country each. Doing it that way would give me a chance to be able to attacked continent purple from two different continents. I would also be able to attack continent green from a couple different continents. Giving me the opportunity to be able to make these attacks and perhaps win them. From there I could march on and keep battling troops and conquering more countries.

I wanted to control the Yellow continent since it was empty. I decided to put all my troops on yellow in three different countries. I chose to put 4 troops in Yellow B so that they would be able to defend from any troops coming from continent red. I put 5 troops in Yellow C because it would give me a chance to attack continent blue and defend myself from attacks launched from blue by the grey player. I put 4 troops in country D because I can launch an attack on the black player on continent green from there. All of these moves will give me a great shot of gaining troops from territories that are close together.

My strategy was to establish a stronghold over a continent while also maximizing the mobility of my troops over the course of the game so that I can expand my army quickly in the early stages of the game. First I placed troops on three countries in yellow C, yellow D, yellow B. This gives me control over continent yellow and ensures I have access to blue and green.  By having at least 2 troops in each border country, I can make sure that all of my Yellow countries are ready to defend the continent.

My first step was to make sure that I had a good amount of troops on Red. Red only has one continent (Green) that it has to defend and has a number of attack access points. I placed 5 troops, although, I feel like I should have done 6, in order to attack and defend. I then was interested in Blue. If I can take over Red, Blue becomes somewhat safer, and I also wanted to make sure that I had access to all of the continents. Finally, I placed a couple of troops on Green, just to get a foothold there and impede the other player's progress on taking over Green.

For me the best continents to place my troops on this map were red and purple. Red had one empty country and that was country C. I decided to place a troops this country in order to try to battle the other occupied countries on red as well as have the opportunity to launch attacks on both yellow and blue from that one country. Then I chose to put the remaining 6 troops I had on purple A because that country gives me access to green, so I would have a great opportunity to capture troops and then move on to different continents from there. Placing these 6 troops also allowed me to protect this purple  country from the blue continent.

Red is a good continent to control, having access to all other continents along with only green having access to it. If I can overtake red, and spread to all of the other continents from there, I can have a safe area at which to gain troop and hold for myself. I put all my troops in Red B so that I can quickly eliminate the Black troops in red C. Once I've done this I can attack Green, since there are currently few enemy troops on it. This will possibly make it easier to control.

Here, the other players are widely spread out, and yellow is the least occupied continent. Taking a strong control of yellow at the beginning means it needs to be well-defended from the black player that can attack from RED-C and the grey player from BLUE_A. Making sure YELLOW_C is well-occupied means it can quickly access BLUE_D to attack (but still remain defended from BLUE_A, and a couple pawns in YELLOW_D mean there's a chance to attack GREEN_A quickly.

Since there is only one entrance to red, I want to control it. I can attack all other continents from red, while only having to worry about green as far as enemies go. I put all of my troops on red and can advance out as possible.

I am planning a focused strategy, by limiting deployment of troops in terms of number of countries and continents. I am avoiding battle on territories that are already heavily occupied, since I lack confidence and don't want to immediately lose a lot of troops. I want to establish a stronghold in at least one country in at least 2 territories. That way, I can act as a spoiler to keep other players from taking over the whole board. I chose countries that offered some mobility because of the presence of an arrow. Once I establish a foothold in my initial continent choices, I will move on toward world domination.

Red is the linchpin continent on the board because it has access to all the other continents with one move.  Red also happened to be completely unoccupied, so I took complete control of all Red countries and placed a total of 10 troops there. I also fortified the border of Red by controlling access through Green D with 3 of my troops.  Having control of Red allows me to pick my battles strategically so I can overtake the other continents while also protecting my own interests.

The goal of this strategy is to condense two large sized armies in red and blue, because they are the least defended area and can allow us an easy way to gain two continents (red and blue) without too much trouble. In addition, Red can only be taken by green, which gives that land a defensive advantage. The goal in the beginning of the game is to take over Red A from the Grey player, granting us an immediate continent bonus other people won't have in the early game. At this point, we should concentrate our defense on Red A, the only area we can be attacked from. Red B and Red C should have 2 armies each to maximize their defensive bonuses if attacked, however, if we lose the Red Continent to Green we probably won't have much of a chance left for winning. The rest of my 5 armies should be concentrated on Blue B, which will be used to take over the blue continent. We should generally avoid taking over Blue D first on that continent, as it is an enemy position that can also be fortified from yellow. However, if we move a large force to Blue A, it may prevent the black player from moving pieces into Blue D from Yellow C. If they move too many pieces into blue, it gives us an easier chance to attack from Blue A into Yellow and significantly weaken their position. When attempting attacks throughout the Blue continent, we should choose the smallest and easiest regions to take over first. Utilizing our early country bonuses and territories occupied, we can continue to add troops into blue with the focus of taking it over. Red will not need additional troops, as it will already be heavily fortified on the one area it can be attacked from. Once we have two continents and move into the midgame, our strongest move would be to take over yellow by attacking it from both our Blue and Red continents, using a pincer movement. Once we possess three continents, our goal is to slowly consolidate and make measured movements to whittle away the remaining troops on the board to win.

Starting on yellow continent I place 9 troops on Yellow C and 5 troops on Yellow B. I leave yellow A and D with no troops since they are not immediately vulnerable. Since red has fewer troops on it than blue, Yellow B is of secondary importance and gets less troops. Yellow C is first in importance as it is both vulnerable in one move from the blue continent and able to attack blue continent in one move. Yellow is a decent stronghold secondary to Red and provides a calculated number of battles to defend as well as to begin to evade.

I feel vulnerable on the blue continent. I need to allocate resources to defending it properly. My secondary goal is to take control of the purple continent. I will launch an invasion and take over the world via purple.

I placed a maximum of 4 troops on the yellow and purple continent so as to protect the borders and also have control over the continent. The troops on the red and yellow are also there to attack the blue continent as I intend to also take over the blue continent. I also placed 2 troops on the green and 2 troops on the red to have control over the continent.

Red was the only continent that had no opponents so I thought it might be easy to hold and get bonus troops for, especially considering most other continents were being contested so, although it would be a small bonus, it might give me an initial advantage while other opponents are fighting for bigger continents. Also, only protecting 3 countries gives me a statistical advantage in defending since I don't have to spread my troops out as thin as I would in other continents.

I saw that the continent red had two openings on it. The one country that was occupied by grey there had a minimal number of troops. I decided to put all 14 of my troops on the continent red on the two open countries in order to control that continent. If I do everything correctly, I can win the battle against the one occupied country and have complete control of Red. This will allow me to be able to easily protect Red against attacks. It will also allow me to be able to launch attacks against every single continent on the board, giving me the ability to win a large number of troops from the countries I will be able to control.

My strategy is to maximize mobility and movement early on in the game so that I can have control over numerous continents. I placed troops in as many continents that I could other than the red continent since it was occupied. However, I placed troops in purple e in order to battle for troops that may lead to access in the red continent.

I placed most troops on green to prevent the other player from taking over the territory since the other player has the red territory locked and could attack from that area if there were no troops to prevent the attack. I placed troops in Blue C so that I could easily reach the purple territory in one move rather than the multiple moves it will take the other player and because that area is protected from being attacked in one move. I placed troops in Yellow A to avoid the other player being able to attack in just one move. I spread troops out to make sure that troops cannot all be removed quickly as this makes them more vulnerable to quick attack. I placed troops in Green D to protect troops that are farther into the territory and to trap the other player into attacking one set of troops while depleting their own territory of forces while also making troops they have separated easier to attack from troops that are farther into the territory.

The idea is to get a foothold wherever I can without much occupancy lock down those areas and wait for a chance to attack smaller areas at a time, slowly starting to take over the bigger and stronger areas once we have maintained a strong foothold in purple, blue, yellow, and green.

My main strategy is to defend. place as many troops in a country hopefully enough on a continent then try to gradually spread. I need to carefully watch where other troops are and try to correspond accordingly. My start is to place as many in Red, Green, Yellow, and Blue and then defend borders. I am trying to line borders with troops to help defend and expand territory.

I wanted to occupy the whole of Red to secure the whole continent immediately.  I also thought Purple can be easily overwhelmed and that would be the next continent I occupied wholly.  After that I would attack Green and it's sparsely occupied countries.

I am spreading my army out even more across the world.  I only chose a few select areas before, but now I want to make sure they are all over the continent in case of takeover.  I assume other players will try to attack me, so I must fortify my borders. I do not want unnecessary battles.

I chose to place the most troops on red since the opponents have the most on blue so I would be able to effectively attack and also defend myself. I chose the other placements on yellow and blue to spread my troops out a little and try to take over the continents with the least opponents on them.

I noticed that black was incredibly spread out, so I decided to put 7 troops on Yellow C to prevent being immediately attacked by grey from red but also to take over Yellow continent by attacking Yellow D and then Yellow A. As the Green continent has Green D with 6 enemy troops, I decided I should also take control of this country, So I placed 7 troops in Green C to easily take that. All in all, allowing me control of both Yellow and Green continents, severely dwindling an opponent's forces allowing me to focus more heavily on Grey, and taking over blue and purple continents with ease.

I put most of my troops in the green border so that maybe they will run from me and attack purple or red before I make my way to purple and take over their continent. I also want to take yellow so I put troops in the other yellow spot and the bordering blue spot.

Red has only one other enemy force on it and has access to four different continents (Purple, Blue, Green, and Yellow). I need to control Red, and once I do I will only need to worry about enemies coming through the one access point from green. Since the enemy grey country on Red is not well defended, I can easily take it by putting the bulk of my troops in Red B and C and surrounding it. This will then allow me to horde up troops and stay safe on Red while the other players fight on Green.

In this setup, I am taking control of the Blue continent in its entirety and am playing from a defensive setup. I have no vulnerabilities to immediate attack in any of the Blue countries, but I am position to attack Purple_A from Blue_C. I have also established posts on Yellow_B and Purple_D, which are not vulnerable to immediate attack. I will let black and grey attack one another while I expand and attack black and eventually grey from positions in which they should not be able to immediate retaliate against my attacks.

I want to move as far east as possible. I chose areas that covered a top, middle and bottom area. My hope is to not play too defensive and end up being trapped thus closing but I wanted to cover as much area as I could. I wanted to make sure that I have troops in a Yellow territory to start with because it is usually highly sought after.

I really like the advantage that green gives me. I will have easy access to get the one remaining set of troops out of there and take control. I am also in a good position to move my troops to surrounding territories. I like the odds this move gives me to fully control the map.

The strategy for the provided board requires maintaining control of the yellow continent and proceeding to attack the blue continent to increase troop reinforcements as quickly as possible. Surrounding enemy territories is irrelevant; the goal is simply to eliminate units from each continent as quickly as possible. Maximizing the number of countries at the beginning of the game is not an important goal; spreading out troops makes them too vulnerable to attack from other players. Keeping all forces grouped together makes both the probabilities of successful attack and defense higher than keeping troops spread across the available countries on the board. Minimizing the number of battles fought is additionally important; any battle should advance the goal of seizing new territories, but defensive battles should be avoided at all costs to minimize troop losses. Fortifying the four countries on the continent I control will increase the chance of receiving additional troops every turn, which will provide a better chance to achieve the victory condition. Battling a single opponent at a time will reduce that opponents forces while limiting my own loss of units. Keeping all troops on the yellow continent affords the opportunity to attack either green or blue territory, while only requiring the defense of two territories with 5 troops in each. Protecting the borders of yellow will afford a better chance to receive more reinforcements for controlling the continent. Having four countries increases the number of reinforcements received.

Keeping all forces grouped together makes both the probabilities of successful attack and defense higher than keeping troops spread across the available countries on the board. Minimizing the number of battles fought is additionally important; any battle should advance the goal of seizing new territories, but defensive battles should be avoided at all costs to minimize troop losses. Seizing control of the red continent early provides the best advantage, only Red A can be attacked, and so it is the only point where defense is required, affording offensive opportunities against all other continents while limiting the number of troops required to be left on defense of the country and the continent to 11. My main strategy is to take over the weakly occupied blue territory with the full amount of my armies united together in Blue D. The reason why the blue country is important is that it is the most defensible country, with only two attack points. At the moment one of those attack points (yellow C to blue D) is empty, giving us an easier chance to take over without worrying about being attacked. In addition, because the blue country has multiple players on it, there may be additional in-fighting that will support our position. Having such a commanding amount of armies on blue may also act as a deterrent for other players to place additional troops on the blue country. Once the blue continent has been taken over, the goal is to consolidate forces on blue and protect Blue B and Blue D from attack. Defending areas should never have less than 3 or 4 armies, and these positions should never attack other regions unless we've lost a blue region. Defensive positions have the advantage in this game, and as such they should always maintain an amount that gives full rolls in combat (2). Once blue is taken over, the goal is to explore other regions for takeover. Considering yellow is completely empty at the moment, there may be an opportunity to attack from Blue A to Yellow C and take more territories pretty quickly. Last, we should be protected from immediate attack from red considering the contested nature of that zone. When a player fully controls a continent, such as yellow or purple, we should harass those positions regularly to remove their full continent bonus. However, we should never overextend our armies and lose large amounts for one attack, as that will make it easy for someone else to clean out our positions. The main goal of this strategy is to simplify the amount of strategy we need to think about in the early game and intimidate other players by going all in on one location. Our first turn should immediately net us two regions, if not the entire country depending on the rest of the placement. If players place large numbers on blue in order to remove us, we should play more defensively and attack the least occupied region in blue. We want the other players to attack us, as we defensively have a better chance of whittling down their army sizes. However, if players do not place many other armies in blue, we're guaranteed a strong foothold in which to expand across the board.

The strategy gives the player the opportunity to quickly conquer the Red continent. As the red continent is the strongest continent on the board, the player must seek to occupy it as quickly as possible. Once the continent is secured, the player then either plays passively, allowing their reinforcements to build until they have an overwhelming advantage, or they immediately attack either Blue or Yellow, as either of these continents is well suited for defensive play, as both only have a single point to defend if the player already controls the red continent.
